More to the point, the way you describe the actual process makes it sound like laser should be just as effective as electrolysis for permanently killing the hair (as in "never coming back" kill, not just "this one is dead, but another one will replace it eventually" kill). So my question is, temperatues are soaring thanks to us taking mother earth for granted and the damage we've wrecked is going to take pretty long to clean up and we being the imbeciles having our wicked need for more and all around chaos, war and jeoprady are far from accomplishing that.

A 2006 review article in the journal "Lasers in Medical Science" compared intense pulsed light (IPL) epilators and both alexandrite (755nm red laser) and diode lasers (near infrared). The review found no statistical difference in short term effectiveness, but a higher incidence of side effects with diode laser based treatment. Hair reduction after 6 months was reported as 68.75% for alexandrite lasers, 71.71% for diode lasers, and 66.96% for IPL. Side effects were reported as 9.5% for alexandrite lasers, 28.9% for diode lasers, and 15.3% for IPL. All side effects were found to be temporary and even pigmentation changes returned to normal within 6 months.

4:14 This shows why laser hair surgery should more accurately be called permanent hair reduction rather than permanent hair removal. Under ideal circumstances (dark hair/light skin) you can expect 15-30% permanent reduction. For permanent hair removal, electrolysis (where they, one-by-one, stick an electrode in your hair follicle and burn it from the inside) is pretty much your only option. That procedure certainly wouldn't be as visually dynamic, though :)

About cancer- melanin IN SKIN cells (not in that few hairs humans have on arms) protects us from UV radiation that causes cancer. So the question is: does the laser kill skin cells that contain melanin or just melanin in hair. I think that hairs have more melanin than tiny cells so the laser burns just hair. Otherwise, people would have to avoid sun permanently after treatment...
